title: Prognostic Scores: FLIPI – Follicular Lymphoma
summary: Comprehensive guide to FLIPI and FLIPI-2 prognostic scoring systems for follicular lymphoma, including clinical applications and modern molecular integrations.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Follicular lymphoma (FL) is the most common indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) and arises from germinal center B-cells. It typically has a slow, waxing and waning course, often with painless lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms in advanced stages.
A hallmark molecular event is the t(14;18)(q32;q21) translocation, leading to BCL2 overexpression—which inhibits apoptosis and contributes to malignant B-cell survival.
Despite being indolent, FL is considered incurable with conventional therapy, and many patients experience multiple relapses over their lifetime.
To improve clinical risk stratification, two key prognostic models have been developed:

items: FLIPI (2004) – based on OS in the pre-rituximab era.
FLIPI-2 (2009) – developed to better assess PFS in patients treated with rituximab-based regimens.

content.text: 2. Why a Prognostic Score for FL?
Unlike aggressive lymphomas (e.g., DLBCL), FL presents with unique management challenges:

items: Late-stage diagnosis is common, yet initial treatment may be deferred.
Responses to therapy can be excellent, but relapse is expected.
Disease course ranges from decades-long indolence to early aggressive transformation.

content.text: Prognostic scoring tools serve several clinical functions:

items: Estimate overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS).
Predict high-risk events such as early disease progression (POD24).
Help tailor:
Treatment intensity (e.g., watchful waiting vs. immediate therapy).
Maintenance strategies.
Eligibility for transplantation or clinical trials.

content.text: FLIPI was derived from retrospective data of >4,000 patients across 5 countries. It aimed to create a simple, clinically applicable score for estimating OS.
Note: A majority of FL patients fall into intermediate or high-risk categories at diagnosis.
In response to treatment evolution, FLIPI-2 was developed in the rituximab era, aiming to better predict PFS.

rows: FLIPI predates rituximab; FLIPI-2 predates obinutuzumab.
Ignores relevant gene mutations (e.g., TP53, EZH2).
Risk score is fixed at diagnosis and doesn't evolve.
Cannot anticipate response to specific therapies.

content.text: These limitations highlight the need for integrated molecular and dynamic risk models.

items: Patient counseling regarding expected outcomes.
Determining follow-up frequency.
Informing decisions on maintenance rituximab.
Risk stratification in clinical trial design.
Choosing between frontline regimens.
Eligibility for transplantation or CAR-T cell therapy.
Estimating risk of transformation to aggressive lymphoma.
POD24: Progression of disease within 24 months of initiating frontline therapy.
Strongly associated with poor overall survival and increased mortality.
FLIPI has limited ability to predict POD24.

content.text: More precise tools such as m7-FLIPI aim to improve prediction of POD24 and transformation risk.

items: Combines:
FLIPI score
ECOG performance status
Mutational status of 7 genes: EZH2, TP53, MEF2B, ARID1A, EP300, FOXO1, CREBBP
Provides:
Enhanced risk stratification.
Prediction of early progression and resistance to immunochemotherapy.
Derived from the PRIMA study.
Uses just:
β2-microglobulin
Bone marrow involvement
Pros: Simpler and bedside friendly.
Cons: Less validated and less granular than m7-FLIPI or FLIPI-2.

content.text: FLIPI remains the most widely used risk model in FL clinical trials due to its simplicity and legacy.

items: Eligibility stratification (e.g., FLIPI ≥3 in high-risk trials).
Subgroup analysis based on baseline risk.
GALLIUM: Compared obinutuzumab vs rituximab-based therapy.
RELEVANCE: R^2 regimen (rituximab + lenalidomide) vs chemoimmunotherapy.

rows: Age, β2M, Hb, Node size, BM

content.text: FLIPI and FLIPI-2 have provided a robust foundation for understanding follicular lymphoma prognosis for two decades. While not suitable for guiding frontline therapy, these scores:

items: Anchor risk discussions with patients.
Inform surveillance strategies.
Guide eligibility and stratification in clinical trials.

content.text: Emerging tools like m7-FLIPI and PRIMA-PI mark a shift toward molecularly integrated prognostics, offering improved prediction of early failure and personalized care strategies.
Still, FLIPI remains the most validated and widely recognized standard, bridging historical context with evolving care paradigms.

items: Use FLIPI for initial risk assessment in newly diagnosed FL
Consider FLIPI-2 for patients receiving rituximab-containing regimens
In high-risk cases, supplement with m7-FLIPI if molecular testing available
Remember FLIPI scores don't dictate therapy choice but inform prognosis
Reassess risk at progression using contemporary tools
